message_1: A company has 10 job openings and 30 applicants who applied for the positions. In how many ways can the company hire exactly 7 out of the 30 applicants?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the combination formula, which is:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where n is the total number of applicants (30 in this case), k is the number of applicants to be hired (7 in this case), and ! denotes the factorial of a number.

So, we have:

C(30, 7) = 30! / (7!(30-7)!)

C(30, 7) = 30! / (7!23!)

Now, we can calculate the factorials:

30! = 30 × 29 × 28 × ... × 3 × 2 × 1
7! = 7 × 6 × 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1
23! = 23 × 22 × 21 × ... × 3 × 2 × 1

Plugging these values into the formula:

C(30, 7) = (30 × 29 × 28 × ... × 3 × 2 × 1) / ((7 × 6 × 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1) × (23 × 22 × 21 × ... × 3 × 2 × 1))

C(30, 7) = 2035800

So, there are 2,035,800 ways the company can hire exactly 7 out of the 30 applicants.
